importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, highlighting the timing of the severe air pollution event in New Delhi immediately following the Diwali festival.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period immediately after Diwali, a major cultural festival in India, saw a spike in air pollution due to fireworks and firecracker use, exacerbating an already critical pollution crisis.

keyTakeAways: New Delhi experienced some of the world’s most polluted air in a single day after Diwali, with PM2.5 levels exceeding 40 times the WHO's annual guideline.
Firecrackers—especially non-green varieties—contributed significantly to air pollution, despite a Supreme Court-allowed ban on traditional firecrackers and a limited window for green alternatives.
Poor enforcement of firecracker restrictions led to widespread use of polluting firecrackers well beyond the legal time window.
India’s long-standing struggle with air pollution is compounded by seasonal stubble burning in surrounding regions and a lack of effective, strictly enforced policies.
Multiple cities across India, including Kolkata and Mumbai, were ranked among the world’s most polluted, indicating a nationwide environmental crisis.
Residents reported severe health effects such as sore throats and eye irritation, underscoring the human impact of poor air quality.
Previous pollution mitigation efforts, such as traffic restrictions and smog towers, have proven insufficient due to lack of enforcement and coordination.

summaryOfNewsArticle: After Diwali celebrations, New Delhi experienced one of the worst air pollution crises in the world, with PM2.5 levels more than 40 times above the World Health Organization’s safe limits. This spike was primarily attributed to the widespread use of firecrackers—especially non-green varieties—despite a Supreme Court permit allowing limited use of 'green' alternatives. Poor enforcement and availability of polluting firecrackers led to significant respiratory health impacts on residents, with long-term public health concerns. The pollution crisis is further intensified by seasonal stubble burning in surrounding agricultural areas and decades of ineffective environmental policies, such as traffic restrictions and smog towers. Other Indian cities like Kolkata and Mumbai were also among the world’s most polluted, indicating a systemic national environmental issue that reflects broader challenges in balancing economic growth with environmental sustainability.
title: After festival of lights, New Delhi plunged into toxic darkness and world’s most polluted air
